fields.description: There is a limitation of iOS emulator that it can only run only one instance per machine. To get around this, for each extra iOS simulator you wish to run create new user accounts for (simulator1, similator2, etc) and run a new Bamboo remote agent on each account.
fields.summary: Support multiple iOS simulators on a single machine

fields.description: Please make it possible to have code coverage reports in Bamboo for  html, text, lcov and cobertura formats.
fields.summary: Code coverage reports in Bamboo for Cobertura

fields.description: Add script task for after build completes that compares md5 sums for files and only uploads if there is a mis match.  Essentially only copy changed files using Git + SCP in Bamboo, rather that re-upload all the files every time a new change is made.
fields.summary: Only upload files that have changed

fields.description:
When we have created a submodule using the absolute URL, the submodules are usually checked out correctly but if this settings is changes to use the relative paths, it fails with eerrors like:

{noformat}
Caused by: com.atlassian.bamboo.plugins.git.GitCommandException: command 'C:\Program Files (x86)\Git\bin\git.exe' submodule update --init --recursive failed with code 1. Working directory was [D:\atlassian\BAMBOO\atlassian-bamboo-4.4.5\HOME\xml-data\build-dir\TESTA-SUBMODULE2-JOB1]., stderr:
30-Apr-2013 19:29:07 	Submodule 'new' (d:/atlassian/BAMBOO/atlassian-bamboo-4.4.5/HOME/xml-data/build-dir/new.git) registered for path 'new'
30-Apr-2013 19:29:07 	Cloning into 'new'...
30-Apr-2013 19:29:07 	fatal: 'd:/atlassian/BAMBOO/atlassian-bamboo-4.4.5/HOME/xml-data/build-dir/new.git' does not appear to be a git repository
30-Apr-2013 19:29:07 	fatal: Could not read from remote repository.
30-Apr-2013 19:29:07 	Please make sure you have the correct access rights
30-Apr-2013 19:29:07 	and the repository exists.
30-Apr-2013 19:29:07 	Clone of 'd:/atlassian/BAMBOO/atlassian-bamboo-4.4.5/HOME/xml-data/build-dir/new.git' into submodule path 'new' failed
30-Apr-2013 19:29:07 	        at com.atlassian.bamboo.plugins.git.GitCommandProcessor.runCommand(GitCommandProcessor.java:431)
30-Apr-2013 19:29:07 	        at com.atlassian.bamboo.plugins.git.GitCommandProcessor.runSubmoduleUpdateCommand(GitCommandProcessor.java:302)
30-Apr-2013 19:29:07 	        at com.atlassian.bamboo.plugins.git.NativeGitOperationHelper.checkout(NativeGitOperationHelper.java:384)
30-Apr-2013 19:29:07 	        ... 22 more
30-Apr-2013 19:29:07 	Caused by: com.atlassian.utils.process.ProcessException: Non-zero exit code: 1
30-Apr-2013 19:29:07 	        at com.atlassian.utils.process.PluggableProcessHandler.complete(PluggableProcessHandler.java:83)
30-Apr-2013 19:29:07 	        at com.atlassian.utils.process.ExternalProcess.finish(ExternalProcess.java:376)
30-Apr-2013 19:29:07 	        at com.atlassian.utils.process.ExternalProcess.execute(ExternalProcess.java:419)
30-Apr-2013 19:29:07 	        at com.atlassian.bamboo.plugins.git.GitCommandProcessor.runCommand(GitCommandProcessor.java:423)
30-Apr-2013 19:29:07 	        ... 24 more
30-Apr-2013 19:29:07 	Failed to prepare the build 'TESTA-SUBMODULE2-JOB1-7'
{noformat}

My .gitmoduless looks like:
{code}
[submodule "new"]
	path = new
	url = ../new.git
{code}

This got translated to {{d:/atlassian/BAMBOO/atlassian-bamboo-4.4.5/HOME/xml-data/build-dir/new.git}} instead of https://github.com/smaiyaki/new.git. I understand that the submodule does not yet support the relative path and we believe this will be a good alternative for users.

*workaround*
# Disable submodules
# crate a script task right after the checkout task to run the following commands
{code}
git remote add origin https://github.com/smaiyaki/new.git
git submodule update --init --recursive
git remote remove origin
{code}

Another painful workaround would be to add additional checkout tasks for each of the submodule
fields.summary: support relative paths in git submodule paths

fields.description:
There are lots of stuff spat out to logs at the end of the build.  A lot of it is unnecessary and a little confusing.

We should get rid of anything that is irrelevant.
fields.summary: Revise and minimise log lines in Build Completed output

fields.description:
When we select a "Command" task, the system give us a panel to choose the executable in a dropdown menu. SInce we don't have any configured executable, we need to add a new executable. The system is not showing this option for non system-administrator users, so even an account with administration privileges is unable to add a new executable and properly configure this kind of task. Please take a look on the following screenshots:


*_With System Administration privileges_*

!https://jira.atlassian.com/secure/attachment/88267/Screen%20Shot%202013-03-14%20at%203.48.39%20PM.png!


*_Without System Administration privileges (but on administrators group)_*

!https://jira.atlassian.com/secure/attachment/88268/Screen%20Shot%202013-03-14%20at%204.02.27%20PM.png!
fields.summary: Users without system administration privileges cannot add new executables on Executable Dropdown Menu on Bamboo Command task.

fields.description:
Steps to re-produce:

1. Make sure you have some branches in Subversion that are detected by Bamboo
2. Check that all of them are enabled
3. Make sure that the "Automatically manage branches" is checked with the default value of 30 days
4. Use a different path, other than default for the Branches Root URL (Ex. : https://seideh-xps13/svn/TestSVNRepo/trunk/branches).
5. Edit a branch repository URL to point to a sub-directory of  [branch location]/[branch name] for example: https://seideh-xps13/svn/TestSVNRepo/trunk/branches/AnotherBranch2/SubSub
6. Notice that right after saving this change or on the next cycle of branch detection, the branch gets disabled.

Check the attached screenshot, both "AnotherBranch1" and "AnotherBranch2" got disabled after these changes.

* Changing the "Remove after" value to "0" days is the workaround to this problem at the moment.
fields.summary: Bamboo disables plan branches when automatic manage branches is enabled

fields.description: When plan names are greater than ~40 characters, not enough information is visible to know which project/plan to select. It's very time consuming to type the whole name of the plan specially when the difference in the names are in the last characters. It will also be great to show more than ten entries in this box, for example if under a project called Project3, I have Plan1 to Plan 15, typing "Plan" will only show me ten records.
fields.summary: Extend the "search for plan" text box length under dependencies tab and make it show more than ten options

fields.description: Can we have thresholds for different Bamboo load parameters and send notifications when the load increases up to the critical zone. Is there a way to predict what's going on with Bamboo's performance in advance and prevent crashes?
fields.summary: Threshold notifications for Bamboo performance

fields.description: The build expiry at the moment can be configured globally. It can also be configured at plan level overriding the global settings. It will be nice to extend this to branch level as well to override the plan configuration. Th idea is to be able to expire branch builds only or expire them more aggressively.
fields.summary: Make build expiry configurable at branch level

fields.description:
If you want to create a branch build manually, you have to lazily (More...) browse through all branches in a lexicographical order until you find the branch for which you want to create a branch build. If there's already an automatic branch configuration present, your repository is most likely containing a lot of branches adhering to this pattern. This means it's quite tedious to browse through the branches if the branch comes after these branches adhering to the pattern.

E.g. in Confluence there are currently 1252 branches starting with issue/, meaning if you've got a branch name ninja you'd have to browse through all of these. Although this is a matter of housekeeping, like deleting branches that have been merged in one of the upstream branches, I believe having a search on that dialog is a valid use case (similar to the *g*oto *b*uild dialog).
fields.summary: (Fuzzy) search for "Create Branch" dialog

fields.description:
Steps to re-create:
1. Check the Change Subversion branches URL checkbox
2. Enter a URL other than the default into the Subversion Branches URL box and save the changes
3. Go to a different tab, for example dependencies and make a change, like un-checking the "Trigger dependencies only when all Stages have been run successfully" box and save changes
4. If you go back to the branches tab now, the "Change Subversion branches URL" checkbox is now unchecked.

*The screenshots are from 4.4.0 but testing this on 4.4.5 gave me the same result.
*If you uncheck the "Automatically detect root URL for branches" checkbox from under the "Advanced" repository options and add a different than default URL for branches there (Ex.: https://seideh-xps13/svn/TestSVNRepo/trunk/branches), it still behaves the same and entering a URL other than the default into the Subversion Branches URL box under the Branches tab (Ex. : https://seideh-xps13/svn/TestSVNRepo/trunk/branches/AnotherBranch1), gets disables after making changes under a different tab.
fields.summary: "Change Subversion branches URL" checkbox gets unchecked after editing another tab

fields.description:
Steps to reproduce:
1. Setup a global password variable in bamboo
2. Setup a build plan with branches
3. Configure the branch 
4. Override a variable, when you choose the password variable, the global password is exposed to the user. 

Please check the attached screenshots.
fields.summary: Mask the password "Value" when overriding global variables in a branch

fields.summary: Bamboo parses special characters in git handler

fields.description: We had one very long build and it's severely impacting the build estimate. See the attached screenshot for more detail.
fields.summary: don't include outliers in build time estimate

fields.description:
Currently Bamboo doesn't offer any "real-time" icon/image for a certain build that be nested/linked into a web page like other build systems (such as travis-ci offer: http://about.travis-ci.org/docs/user/status-images/)

The rest interface does give access to the build status but one still needs to do REST interaction and add in some logic to return the icon.
Further more in cases like github, where javascript is not allowed in web pages, one has to create her own service.
fields.summary: embeddable build status image/icon

fields.description:
The {{seraph.bamboo}} cookie does not use the {{HttpOnly}} or {{secure}} attributes. This increases impact from XSS and network based attacks. These attributes must be set, as is already the case with {{JSESSIONID}}.

If the {{HttpOnly}} attribute is set on a cookie, then the cookie’s value cannot be ready or set by client-side JavaScript. This measure can prevent certain client-side attacks, such as cross-site scripting, from trivially capturing the cookie’s value via an injected script. If the {{secure}} flag is set on a cookie, then browsers will not submit the cookie in any requests that use an unencrypted HTTP connection, thereby preventing the cookie from being trivially intercepted by an attacker monitoring network traffic.
fields.summary: Seraph remember me cookie is not using HttpOnly or Secure attributes

fields.description:
I have an atlassian licensed plugin. Licensing and remote agents don't seem to go well together :(. 

I have removed all license checks from the task run time to avoid problems with components not being available. See https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/45157/unsatisfieddependencyexception. All seems well and the task runs fine on both local and remote. License checking is only done at configuration time which runs on the local server.

However, if the build needs to report failure on the target system, then after all the task code is complete, Bamboo seems to be trying to access the configuration when it is completing the task. This give a messy failure.

What is going on? Is there some other techniques that are suppose to be used to do licensing and support remote agents that I am not aware of?

fields.description:
Now that you hide password values on this screen, it is hard to track what the value is represented by the variable. A description field would be useful to document setting or usage. Another alternative would be to allow at least the system admin to see the real value.

Part of the problem is that is that you don't allow composite (recursive) global variables so that one variable cannot reference another variable. So, in many cases a password needs to be embedded in a longer substitution variable (and have a name that contains password) to get the hiding in the build log. fields.description:
Trivial from a priority perspective, but:

We have a secondary repository containing most of our deployment-for-internal-testservers tools; this code is shared among multiple plans (but set not to trigger builds), and for the most part is versioned along with the actual code, but the following situation occasionally arises:

PLAN-A gets committed to; PLAN-B, with both the plan-b repo and the tools repo, is built as a dependency of PLAN-A; no changes have occurred to the plan-b repo but changes _have_ occurred to the tools repo; PLAN-B fails due to a dependency change in PLAN-A; committers to the tools repo are marked as potentially responsible for the failure.

Being able to set metadata on the responsibility aspect of a plan the same way I can indicate triggers for the various source repositories of the plan would simply eliminate confusion over who was actually responsible for the build failure.

Minor, but wanted to note the potential improvement.
fields.summary: Ability to mark non-primary repositories as "not responsible"

fields.description:
I have been successfully keeping my branches up to date by manually merging master into my branch, pushing to origin, and then having Bamboo checkout and build my branch. I tried using Branch Updater so that Bamboo could automate this merging. However, doing so breaks my build.

My builds produce artifacts named using the git SHA of the HEAD revision being built. While Branch Updater does merge master into the branch during the Source Code Checkout task, it does so without creating a commit. Only at the end of the build does a commit get created and pushed.

Therefore, during the build, despite the working copy and git index containing the merged files, because there is no commit "git rev-parse HEAD" still reports the SHA of the latest commit of the branch. As a result the artifacts I produce are labelled incorrectly (they are named as if they contain pre-merge content while they actually contain post-merge content).

Please change Bamboo to commit the merge at the end of the Source Code Checkout stage instead and push that commit at the end of the build (if successful of course). With this approach, not only would the local git repo more accurately represent what is happening in the build, but I could use Branch Updater and still name my artifacts appropriately.
fields.summary: Provide the git SHA that will be pushed by Branch Updater as a build variable

fields.description:
I have a bamboo job that I set up to run concurrently however I only have a single agent that is configured to run it. The reason I do this is because I am hosting a performance testing environment and the agent itself acts as the "gatekeeper" to insure that one and only one job runs within the environment at a time. 

In order to allow my users to submit their jobs whenever they would like to, I configured the plan to run concurrently. As mentioned above, concurrency is not really possible because only one agent can run this job.

I noticed that when jobs are queued, the durration reported for them begins at the moment the job was submitted, NOT when the job started executing. I believe this to be incorrect behavior. I believe that the value of durration should report the time the job was actually executing, without adding in the time that it was queued waiting for an agent.
fields.summary: Incorrect build durration reported when job is concurrent and queued

fields.description:
Steps to reproduce (within a plan that connects to a SCM with branches)
# Configure a plan variable
# Create a branch
# Configure the variable with a value (and for instance... pass it as -Dvar=${bamboo.varname} in a maven task)
# (maybe execute the plan, don't know if it is necessary)
# Delete the branch
# Create a new branch
# Configure the variable to have a different value
# Run the plan
* The value passed to the task is the old one

I think this may relate to the fact that bamboo names branches as "<plan-name> + index", and this does not take the deleted branches history into account, so my <bamboourl>/PLAN0 branch already existed and it is using the values that were configured in that old branch.
fields.summary: Plan branches use old (deleted) branches variable values

When the build is run with the private key from the plan placed in the {{~/.ssh/}} of the Bamboo agent, the build succesfully checks out all git submodules.

I would expect that as a user of Bamboo that I wouldn't have to distribute the SSH private key to all Bamboo remote agents; rather just have the private key kept as a part of the plan configuration.

This way, the build infrastructure could scale in respect to not having to have a ssh-agent with all the SSH private keys loaded in for all git submodule based builds that are required to be built on these agents.

Therefore Bamboo could leave the power of configuration up to the users of bamboo instead of the infrastructure administrators of the build agents.

Seems an important enough setting to have in the administration panels.

fields.description:
We have some instances where the SCP-Task tries to create a remote directory named after the file that should've been uploaded.

E.g. we tried uploading a file "main.min.js", which resulted in:
"Creating remote directory 'dist/js/main.min.js'..
[...]
Copy Failed. Some files were not uploaded successfully.
'dist/js/main.min.js' was not uploaded."

First assumption was a problem with files containing a dot in the filename itself. But we also have files like this, which are uploaded successfully.

One interesting differentiation for the "main.min.js"-case is the fact that we have files in the same directory called "main.min.js.src" and "main.min.js.map". Could this be related?

In another instance of this problem, we had a file called "name_of_file.pdf" which was sitting alongside a file "name_of_file.pdf_old". Which, too, resulted in this error.

We are using "Atlassian Bamboo version 4.4.4 build 3506" and "Bamboo SCP and SSH Tasks Version: 1.18"
fields.summary: SCP-Task mistakenly trying to create remote directories for files

fields.description:
Currently in my setup I can successfuly able to have branches automatically created from my Git repository and the associated Branch Plans automatically created and this works great! I have the defaults set to do automatic merging via the Branch Updater approach and as well configured to merge from the Parent Plan and then push onto the Branch.

Based on the documentation it appears to me that the following should happen but doesn't appear to be, and for this sake we'll say that I have the Parent Plan on master and created a branch called feature/A-1 and Bamboo has everything described above configured.

# Developer commits code to master
# Bamboo detects change and builds the master via the Parent Plan
# Parent Plan builds successfully
# Bamboo then builds the Branch Plan for feature/A-1 since a change happened in the master

Step 4 is the one that isn't happening. Everything else works just fine. if I actually commit something on the Branch feature/A-1 then the Branch Plan will run merging the master first running the plan, then on success pushing the master onto the branch feature/A-1

It would be nice if the Branch Plans would automatically build when the master does as well, to help make sure that the branch isn't diverging too far from the master.
fields.summary: Bamboo Auto Merge with Branch updater
Error: "Unable to get build result since buildNumber was not specified"

fields.description:
*Premises:*
* Bamboo 4.4 integrated with Crowd 2.5.3
* All users have valid emails, and are mapped to repository committers
* Bamboo is sending email notifications

*Bamboo configuration:*
* Repository commiter: fkraemer
* Bamboo user details (imported from Crowd):
** Username: fkraemer
** Email: fkraemer@atlassian.com
** Source Repository Alias: fkraemer
* Plan Notifications:
** Event: Failed Jobs And First Successful
** Recipient Type: Responsible (users who are responsible for the current failure)

*Steps I've followed and results:*
# I Created a new plan, containing only the Source Code Checkout task, and ran it for the first time.
# Build #1 was successful, and no notifications were sent, as expected.
# I added a task that forces the job to fail
# I committed code into the repository, using committer fkraemer
# Build #2 failed, but no email was sent to fkraemer@atlassian.com (first failed job - it should have sent an email)
# I committed code into the repository again, without changing plan configuration, using committer fkraemer
# Build #3 failed, but this time an email was sent to fkraemer@atlassian.com (second failed job)
# I removed the failing task from the job
# I committed code into the repository, using committer fkraemer
# Build #4 was successful, and an email was sent to fkraemer@atlassian.com (first successful, email sent as expected)
# I committed code into the repository again, without changing plan configuration, using committer fkraemer
# Build #5 was successful, and no email was sent to fkraemer@atlassian.com (as expected)

Before trying this with Crowd integrated, using a local Bamboo user, having the same configuration, and following the same steps, the responsible user received an email for the first failed job, so this is indeed related to Crowd.

A workaround is add another notification for "First failed job for plan" to "Committers".

Please see the screenshot attached showing the behavior mentioned above.
fields.summary: First failed job not sending email to responsible user when Bamboo is integrated with Crowd

fields.description:
*Steps to reproduce*
# I have two test files to be parsed by Bamboo. One of them is wellformed with classname and has 16 test cases while the other one does not have the classname and only a single test case.
# The directory for which the test files are placed does not really matter
# Create a JUNIT task to parse those results
# The build result will return that 16 tests total and 17 tests have passed.This is quite misleading as per the screenshot.

Bamboo should have not parsed the test result from the other file and return just 16 test results. It is worth mentioning that the build is testless if we try to parse only the result file with invalid format

fields.description:
The Bamboo UI for editing a Bitbucket repository on a plan, attempts to load the repositories and branches for the list. When this load occurs on a repository that has been deleted with a redirect, Bitbucket serves a full page 404 with the new location of the repository.

The Bamboo API then takes the full contents of this page and renders an error to the Bamboo UI. The ui, in turn, loads ALL the resources from the error page, including the javascript and images. This breaks the UI and could be a security issue.



To reproduce:
# Create a new plan in Bamboo using a Bitbucket repository
# Verify that this plan functions as expected
# Create a new repo
# Delete the old repo in Bitbucket, but set a redirect
# Attempt to change the plan in Bamboo, this should fail and you'll see data loading from Bitbucket's cdn
fields.summary: Loading the branches from a Bitbucket repository that has been deleted and redirected will result in issues

08-Apr-2013 09:48:16	Starting task 'Parse results' of type 'com.atlassian.bamboo.plugins.testresultparser:task.testresultparser.junit'
08-Apr-2013 09:48:16	Parsing test results...

fields.description:
An old bug (possibly related to BAM-10623) has resurfaced. It was fixed in Bamboo 4.3.2 but has come back to haunt us in 4.4.4.

When we clone a job, no matter what plan it came from, it executes in a completely inappropriate directory and therefore can't find the files it is attempting to run/use. It attempts to execute in a Bamboo agent local directory. See screenshot.

When this happens, it affects the target job, and sometimes also the source job.

Our only workaround is to edit the tasks and modify the Working Subdirectory settings (and then modify them back).

I haven't seen this problem with entire plans, only individual jobs.

Good grief, this is maddening! It's such a pain in the neck that I bumped it from minor to major.
fields.summary: Cloned jobs execute in wrong directory: Regression!

fields.description:
We have verified that, as of the installation of Bamboo 4.3.2 (and now 4.4.4), all build tasks launched by Bamboo on a Windows agent run as user System, even though the Bamboo agent is running as a different user. This did not used to be true.

I have attached a screen shots of a a script task's script and the output log of that job during a build. All agents involved are executed as user "build", but the spawned task processes clearly show that they are running as user "System", despite using build's user profile.

To reiterate: this is a change in how Bamboo used to run, and we don't want our build tasks running as the System user, ever.
fields.summary: Bamboo agents on MS Windows run as specified user, but spawned processes run as user SYSTEM.

fields.summary: Maintain labels casing

fields.description:
The current default behavior when you set the *Automatically manage branches* check-box (under *Branches* inside *Plan Configuration*) is to only add branches that are created after the option is set, so if you have existing branches you'll have to add those manually (using the Create Branch button).

It would be clearer for users if when you set the *Automatically manage branches* option Bamboo scanned for any previous existing branches and gave you the option to add those. Users can get confused on why Bamboo is not detecting their existing branches (when in fact they need to add it manually).
fields.summary: Automatically manage branches option should pick up already existing branches.

fields.description:
Currently when the agent times out Bamboo sends a shutdown command to EC2. When you stop the server, your current build state of projects is preserved, you are then able to resume the server in it's last state. When the agent next launches it must either use whats in the AMI or the attached EBS volume which means all changes since the AMI/EBS was created are lost.

If Bamboo could instead send a 'Stop' command EC2 will keep that server's volume intact ready for the next time the server is started.
fields.summary: Stop a Bamboo Elastic instance instead of Terminate

fields.description:
Steps to re-create:

1. Define a Plan Variable (Plan Configuration -> Variables)
2. Give it a password-like name. According to the documentation, Bamboo should hide the value if the name includes the word "password".
3. Create a branch for the plan.
4. Go to override the variables for the branch. The initial value of the "hidden" password variable will be visible.

This value should be hidden like what we see when selecting Run Customized. 

Please check the attached screenshot. I tested this on both 4.4.4 and 4.4.5.
fields.summary: Hide the password "Value" when overriding plan variables in a branch

fields.description:
At first glance, the Quarantined Tests page for a plan does not sort in any particular order. It does seem to group by the job, but the order of Jobs is not alphabetical.

Ideally, the list would have interactive sort capabilities.

Minimally, the list should be sorted in an initiative consistent way, especially to make comparing plan branches/other plans easier.
fields.summary: Quarantined Tests page does not have a consistent sort order

fields.description: Per ISO8601, '2013-03-31T09:57:00.457+04:00' is the extended version of '20130332T095700.457+0400'; However, colons can be problematic in file and path operations, unless escaped, making it more difficult to handle such operations if build results or artifacts want to make use of the buildTimeStamp. Adding the basicBuildTimeStamp variable as built-in would make it simple to use this in any scenario.
fields.summary: Expose bamboo.basicBuildTimestamp in addition to the extended timestamp currently available

fields.description:
Disabling Automatic Dependency management does not remove the generated dependencies.

Procedure to reproduce:
 - someone turned on automatic dependency management with maven 2 for our plans, as a "final task" for the mvn clean install job, while we were on bamboo 4.2.1.
 - This caused plans to start cascading.
 - I disabled automatic dependency management, but the builds were still happening; the "generated" items could not be removed.
 - I read about bug  BAM-12760, and upgraded to bamboo 4.4.4 in order to fix things.
 - The generated dependencies are still there, and can't be removed.
 - deleting the automatic dependency management final task does nothing; things still cascade.

I think I am doing something wrong, or the fix isn't working properly.
fields.summary: Disabling Automatic Dependency management does not remove the generated dependencies.

fields.description:
Actual: Gatekeeper by default starts the build by merging the branch to master. This creates a merge commit in the history.

The Bamboo UI for the build page says something like:
Checked out: branch a1b2c3d4
Merged with: master f9e8d7c4

Desired: We'd rather rebase the branch onto master at the start of our Gatekeeper builds and force push the branch, to avoid the merge commit. There would be a checkbox in the Gatekeeper option box on the Branches tab, "Rebase branch instead of merging. (git only)" 

The Bamboo UI would then say something like:

Checked out: branch -a1b2c3d4-
Rebased onto: master f9e8d7c4
Pushed: branch 8a6b4c2a

This requires a bit of justification. First, why do we want it? And second, how could this be safe?

For background, we only want to use Gatekeeper for short-term (often single-commit) bug branches. For long-lived branches, we'll prefer to use Branch Updater and merge back to master manually at the end of the branch, most likely after a pull request.

We want Gatekeeper to do rebases because doing a merge commit for a branch with just a single commit on it messes up the revision history, which has an impact when we use git-bisect. Here are a couple of blog posts talking about why it's a good idea to use rebase or merge --squash when you land small branches on master, instead of merging.

https://sandofsky.com/blog/git-workflow.html
http://blog.izs.me/post/37650663670/git-rebase

You may or may not be convinced by those articles, but I hope you can at least see why _someone_ would want to do it that way, even if you don't approve of it for yourself!

For reasons like this, at our organization we always do "git pull --rebase" when we do our pulls.

You may have heard that rebasing public branches is inherently unsafe. This is basically good advice, but it's overblown. The publicity of the branch isn't what really matters; it's whether people have committed work on top of rebased commits.

Rebasing history is dangerous if other people have made commits on top of commits that you're rebasing, because it will force them to rebase their commits (by hand!) on top of your new rebased head. One way you can be sure that it's safe to rebase is if the branch is completely private and has never left your machine. In that case, it's impossible for anyone else to do a commit based on your private branch. But there are other ways to have reasonable assurances of privacy while still pushing your code to Bitbucket.

For example, if you push a branch whose name is {{private-dgf-BAM-13032}}, it would be very unusual for anyone to decide to arbitrarily start committing in your private branch. It's not impossible, but in practice, it won't happen.

Our goal is to use Gatekeeper only with "private" branches; this wouldn't be enforced in a security sense, but via naming standards and public norms. So in those cases, it's perfectly fine for Gatekeeper to rebase them; the only person who will be impacted when my private branch is rebased is me.

Furthermore, as long as I pull Gatekeeper's rebase into my repository with "git pull --rebase", (which, again, is what we always do at our organization) git will automatically recover from Gatekeeper's upstream rebase, and all will be well.

In conclusion: using Gatekeeper to rebase branches is safe and even desirable if you take reasonable precautions; we'd love it if Gatekeeper would support our workflow.
fields.summary: Allow Gatekeeper to rebase instead of merging
